post_text: Wanted to get everybody‚Äôs feedback. Ôøº I work for a home health agency that contracts home physical therapy visits to a local hospice. Ôøº Usually Ôøºwe only get four visits at most.Ôøº Our focus is home safety and fall prevention and a home exercise program. My home health company is sending me back to see Ôøº a hospice patient that I just discharged, Ôøº even though the hospice previously did not authorize any further visits. There is no skilled PT indicated as caregivers are already providing range of motion and the patient is bedbound. Ôøº the home care company is asking me to do a full-blown Medicare Oasis assessment  even though the services are  through hospice and only 4 visits. Ôøº The home health company is telling me it‚Äôs OK to see this patient even though I am not providing a skilled service. May be legal but is this ethical?

comments.text: Sometimes the role in hospice is to provide services as the person declines. In the case of PT, perhaps positioning, cushion recommendations, etc. Hospice is a much different, more limited approach. What is the reason? Is family requesting assistance with something? Is there an increase in pain? If there is a new need, then an OASIS would be needed to establish POC if nursing has discharged? But, that seems unlikely. Assuming nursing is still seeing, wouldn't PT eval suffice? I am confused on these details. Is there a wound?

There was a change in federal law that went into effect Dec1 that all patients have an oasis regardless of payor. Often in situations like that, there are new caregivers or a complete change in caregiver and they require new education which is skilled.

post_text:
Looking for the good, bad, and the ugly of home health jobs. 

Considering leaving my FT outpatient (completely inflexible) position to a PT home health job (for flexibility) to progress into more full-time with my side.

What are things I need to ask or need to be aware of when interviewing? 

Anonymous for privacy from others in my immediate area.

comments.text:
I think it totally depends on how the company runs. I do HH and enjoy it and feel I‚Äôm compensated well. The pros are that you don‚Äôt have to take time off to go to an apt. I can really start and end my day whenever I want (to a degree). 
I would definitely ask if it‚Äôs PPV hourly or salary. How big of a territory do you cover. I do PPV buy territory is fairly small which is great for me. Ask what happens when there isn‚Äôt enough work. Sometimes it‚Äôs feast or famine so there are times it can get really slow. Mileage reimbursement. Do you get paid extra for going outside of your territory? Do they provide all the equipment you need like BP cuff, bag, etc. 
Some of the cons are non hygienic homes, smoking, paperwork somedays but that also gets easier, family dynamics, and at times I feel like I‚Äôm managing other things there isn‚Äôt much time for therapy. A lot of people who are appropriate for HH are very very sick so they tolerate so little and honestly a lot of them don‚Äôt get better so that can be tough. I really enjoy only seeing 1 person at a time and getting to know them and their family in their home.

The good is the flexibility for sure. The bad is the relentless paperwork and time spent on it that seriously when I was in it I think I made $5.00/hr. 
That might be not so true but the time with paperwork is insane esp with start of care.  Also some of the homes were questionable in terms of sanitation.  I went back to outpatient

full_thread_text:
POST: Looking for the good, bad, and the ugly of home health jobs. 

Considering leaving my FT outpatient (completely inflexible) position to a PT home health job (for flexibility) to progress into more full-time with my side.

What are things I need to ask or need to be aware of when interviewing? 

Anonymous for privacy from others in my immediate area.

COMMENT 1: I think it totally depends on how the company runs. I do HH and enjoy it and feel I‚Äôm compensated well. The pros are that you don‚Äôt have to take time off to go to an apt. I can really start and end my day whenever I want (to a degree). 
I would definitely ask if it‚Äôs PPV hourly or salary. How big of a territory do you cover. I do PPV buy territory is fairly small which is great for me. Ask what happens when there isn‚Äôt enough work. Sometimes it‚Äôs feast or famine so there are times it can get really slow. Mileage reimbursement. Do you get paid extra for going outside of your territory? Do they provide all the equipment you need like BP cuff, bag, etc. 
Some of the cons are non hygienic homes, smoking, paperwork somedays but that also gets easier, family dynamics, and at times I feel like I‚Äôm managing other things there isn‚Äôt much time for therapy. A lot of people who are appropriate for HH are very very sick so they tolerate so little and honestly a lot of them don‚Äôt get better so that can be tough. I really enjoy only seeing 1 person at a time and getting to know them and their family in their home.

COMMENT 2: The good is the flexibility for sure. The bad is the relentless paperwork and time spent on it that seriously when I was in it I think I made $5.00/hr. 
That might be not so true but the time with paperwork is insane esp with start of care.  Also some of the homes were questionable in terms of sanitation.  I went back to outpatient

post_text: What is the logistics of starting a Home Health Company?  We are an outpatient neuro clinic and was wondering how feasible is it to start a home health company that is neuro specific? üòù

comments.text:
We have 7 outpatient physical therapy clinics. We opened a home health agency 14 years ago too. 

We are independent in both and have so many experienced clinicians.  I am the director of therapy for the outpatient and Administrator for the home health company.  

It‚Äôs a lot harder to open the home health company.  You have to so much money in an account to show and basically treat the first 10 Medicare patients for free (it was 14 years ago). A lot more regulations for licensing.  Must have a Director of Nursing and the policies and procedures are totally different.  I been through 4 state surveys for both.  Nothing is the same except the emergency preparedness plan we have to maintain for both. We have two 
separate companies and two separate EMRS and billing.  

I feel home health is not patient generated and driven only by discharge planners.  I‚Äôm not sure how much a specialist would do as visits could be limited.  People generally do not have freedom of choice.  The hospitals dictate agencies then if they go to a SNF, they tend to dictate who is picked.  

I personally feel the best way to be a specialist and be sought out is only through outpatient at home.  Not home health. If you want to get into home health , contract with a home health agency first.  

We have so many outpatient therapists that specialize that also do home health, and it does not generate additional business in home health. We are a top provider in outpatient in our area but it never has helped us in home health.

My wife worked in home health for years  and was a Parkinson‚Äôs specialist.  She left her home health company (different than the one I‚Äôm in charge of and it was owned by a hospital) and started a separate outpatient at home business.  She does so much more business as an outpatient provider using her specialty.  

So, basically I have seen outpatient, outpatient at home, and home health through 3 different companies.

Winning formula = contract yourself out to home health agency, see patients for the plan of care. Once the agency discharges, go in as outpatient provider with through indoor self pay. Agencies are limiting home-health visits and patients have such a need after discharge.

I don't think neuro patients would be as profitable because they will require a lot more intensity of care, more visits and likely more disciplines involved. Majority of the time our neuro patients were getting PT, OT, ST, MSW, nursing, and HHA.

We are independent in both and have so many experienced clinicians.  I am the director of therapy for the outpatient and Administrator for the home health company.  

It‚Äôs a lot harder to open the home health company.  You have to so much money in an account to show and basically treat the first 10 Medicare patients for free (it was 14 years ago). A lot more regulations for licensing.  Must have a Director of Nursing and the policies and procedures are totally different.  I been through 4 state surveys for both.  Nothing is the same except the emergency preparedness plan we have to maintain for both. We have two

We have so many outpatient therapists that specialize that also do home health, and it does not generate additional business in home health. We are a top provider in outpatient in our area but it never has helped us in home health.

post_text:
**A big THANK YOU to everyone who posted their take, this was really helpful to navigate this situation. I am unable to respond to each one, but it was great to see the different perspectives. They helped me build a plan of action for how to proceed with my potential patients. Thanks again!!

Advice please: I run a small mobile private pay PT business and I‚Äôm still trying to build my caseload. There‚Äôs a potential patient who is asking for me to come meet him and his wife (also potential patient) at their home, ~30 min drive away.
This couple owns several restaurants in my city and are fairly well-off. This could be a good boost for my company, both as income and referral sources.
What I‚Äôm trying to decide is if I should go drive out to meet this couple (something I never do for free for other patients) or should I ask for a zoom meeting, instead?
I really want and need the business, but I don‚Äôt want my *desperation* to cloud my judgement. 
What makes the most sense to do?

Thanks, in advance!

Edit to clarify: I only mentioned 30 minute drive to highlight it‚Äôs not an easy drop-in for a free consultation. The drive to see this patient is not the issue, as it‚Äôs built into the session price.

comments.text:
Last year I drove 15.5 hours for FREE to see a patient at a large company just for the opportunity to gain their business. One year later, I might be looking at a whole region of locations because of this feat. Could it have been a $600 loss? Sure. 

BUT, I would rather spend that money with a direct face to face marketing opportunity then spending $100 on indirect marketing that likely won't work. These face to face opportunities are worth their weight in gold!

Go the extra mile, be THAT therapist. In a world of people kinda going for it, just go for it. Hold nothing back. ‚ô•Ô∏è

If you are building your business and you have the time, that is all it will cost you. The benefits sound like they far at weigh your time used. If you are great at what you do, you will not only gain 2 paying clients, but also a terrific future referral stream that could be HUGE for your business. I would highly recommend taking the time and going for that consult. People talking about it being offered as ‚Äúfree‚Äù need to understand that free consults should be priced into your visit costs and focus on having a high conversion rate. That is a great model for a successful business! Don‚Äôt get deterred by the drive or the ‚Äúfree‚Äù part, or anything else. Focus on giving a high quality service and letting that lead to future business growth! Big picture! Goodluck!

post_text:
Hoping this encourages someone!
I started my mobile cash business in March. Had a couple patients. Average 1-4 visits a week for the longest time. I was still doing full time home health. 

I resigned from full time HH on October 18th and started doing 5-10 prn visits for them a week and have been focusing on my business. 

This week, I have 12 visits with 1 client out of state who would have made this week 14. I have been consistently seeing 8-10 weekly for a month. 

I only need 15 a week @ $150 to replace my home health pay. (They cut my pay 20% in January)

I have paid for ads, done a couple spots on the news, and done a few other things for marketing that cost a little. 

Didn‚Äôt get much from that. 

I‚Äôve been mostly focusing on building relationships with other business owners and local providers through podcast interviews, spending time with them when I can, going to business open house events, using a local business bartering service (Moxey). 

I know we are all different and in different locations, but be patient with yourself and  focus on a couple things with as big return as you can get. 

Be clear what you do for people and don‚Äôt sheepishly quote your price when people ask! Be confident! 

I haven‚Äôt made it yet and I don‚Äôt have it all together, but I‚Äôm moving in the right direction and SO CAN YOU! 

For context, there are at least 4 other therapists doing cash PT where I am in Shreveport, LA. Only about 180,000 people.  There‚Äôs plenty of business for us all! 

Most people are blue collar workers just like my dad was. People value being taken care of and I‚Äôm finding that out the more I push! 

Keep your head up and keep moving forward! 

Don‚Äôt waste time being busy, but be busy doing the things that work!

Forgot this originally. Even though I am still doing prn HH; the mindset shift if I‚Äôm now working on my business and doing part time for them vs part time in my business and HH as my main source WAS HUGE!!

comments.text: Jeremy Sutton Love watching your testimony unfold.  Keep up the great work and thank you for being a light

Nice work!! üôåüèΩ Are you charging for drive time or just writing it off? I‚Äôm doing this as well (combo of HH prn and cash mobile) but some of my mobile pts are more than a half hour drive away‚Ä¶ it definitely cuts down on how many patients I can see if I‚Äôm doing those long drives.

**Edited to add one more question**

I‚Äôve been seeing some posts/comments about contracting with home health companies. I‚Äôm exploring the idea of contracting with a home health company through my LLC. I would love to hear your insights as this is an avenue I have never explored. 

What do you think are the unique benefits for a home health company when they contract with a private practice physical therapist? Whether it‚Äôs specialized skills, flexibility, or something else? What are the unique benefits for the private practice owner or solo practitioner? 

I have minimal experience with the home health setting in general, so what are some pros/cons to consider? Any special considerations when developing a contract?

Is anyone comfortable sharing rates they‚Äôve accepted with home health companies to help develop a realistic proposal?

What are the potential tax benefits (if any) working 1099 for a home health company contracting through your LLC as opposed to working PRN for home health and working under your LLC separately? 

Any thoughts and experiences you would like to share are greatly appreciated!!

post_text:
Hey y‚Äôall. This is a question for everyone who has started their own mobile practice.

What was the main reason you started it?

Looking back at that reason specifically, has it lived up to your expectations?

Also, looking at it now, what are YOUR biggest pros and cons of starting your own mobile practice?

Thank you in advance for your responses.

comments.text:
Less overhead, getting out of my W2 job, being able to provide exceptional care without having insurance dictating what we could do (cash pay practice). Better income potential than W2. And yes would never go back

Pros: flexible schedule, not paying rent for a clinic, pts love the concierge level experience vs what they get with HH

Cons: driving to other pts but isn't that big of a deal

Pro: flexibility, time to research best/updated practices, spending time with patients rather than documenting for the insurance companies, I found a new passion for business operations. 

Con: time that goes into start up, marketing takes $, balancing a job with benefits and slowly decreasing that caseload so I can slowly increase my private pay caseload.

Looking at reaching out to local assisted living facilities for mobile PT, but looking for feedback from those who already do this. 

1. I've heard from many that most of the advantage plans don't allow for mobile visits. Have you found this to be true? And if so, how do you go about explaining that to prospective patients/facility managers?

2. How did you go about contacting the facilities and marketing to patients?

3. Any other feedback/ advice/comments to offer

Thanks everyone!

comments.text: Hi Brooke Terilli. This is primarily what I do in my mobile practice. I‚Äôd be happy to talk with you about it :)

When I was working home healthcare in ALFs, I always wanted to know who the best mobile providers were so we could do a hand-off. 

Do you have relationships with the home health agencies? 

Their biggest concern is usually that they‚Äôll get the patient back after the next hospitalization or adverse event. So I‚Äôd be sure to let them know your plans to refer back to them when the status changes and the client qualifies for home health again. 

Just my take from the HH side. It was all about trust and if we‚Äôd ‚Äúget them back‚Äù or if the outpatient person would try to hold them on their caseload even after a fall/hospitalization/adverse event. üòä

post_text: Anyone else struggling to get their business verified with google? I have watched several videos, followed directions with street address, my house number( I am mobile and treat out of my home), showed my IRS forms and the room I treat and still no luck. (and under two minutes). Any suggestions  out there or success stories? Thanks

comments.text: If you are mobile then choose service area ( if you have not done that)  and not a particular address , that‚Äôs when it will ask for a video verification. I did the mistake of first entering my address  & had to submit multiple videos. Then after I entered as service area business , it got verified in a day .. hope this helps
It's best to chat with support and they can help. They usually submit a ticket and it's fixed in about a week in most cases.

post_text: I am an OT with a mobile practice. I see mainly Med B patients in their homes. My biller said to set the practice location as "Independent clinic" instead of "patient's home". Is this what other people have experienced? Is this so that it doesn't get confused with home health? Any input appreciated. Thank you üôÇ

comments.text: According to CMS chapter 15 section 220 therapists in private practice can see patients in their clinic or the patient's home. I would keep with patient's home to be accurate. Your business should have been credentialed with medicare to see patients in their homes.

post_text: For those of you who went from mobile ‚û°Ô∏è brick and mortar üè£do you have any regrets?  Why did you make the switch?  Any other words of advice?

comments.text: Approx 90% of my practice is still mobile but I have a brick and mortar space that I rent from a prosthetist colleague. Like others said, it fulfilled a mission to collaborate on patients with limb loss and offer a space for older adults. The caseload hasn't grown in the brick and mortar ad I had hoped but I smile every time I put my key in the door and see my logo on the wall so I'm gonna keep it going for a while and see if I can make it work!

I still provide mobile visits but also wanted to have a brick n mortar space to fully live out the vision I have.   I think it‚Äôs important to really think out what you want to do with your business and if having a clinic space helps move you toward that goal.  For me I envisioned having a space that I could host workshops and education seminars to help the community and I wanted to be able to offer other services that can‚Äôt be provided in a mobile setting.

I also think it‚Äôs important not to rush into a space, make sure it‚Äôs the best fit for you before taking the leap.

full_thread_text:
POST: For those of you who went from mobile ‚û°Ô∏è brick and mortar üè£do you have any regrets?  Why did you make the switch?  Any other words of advice?

COMMENT 1: Approx 90% of my practice is still mobile but I have a brick and mortar space that I rent from a prosthetist colleague. Like others said, it fulfilled a mission to collaborate on patients with limb loss and offer a space for older adults. The caseload hasn't grown in the brick and mortar ad I had hoped but I smile every time I put my key in the door and see my logo on the wall so I'm gonna keep it going for a while and see if I can make it work!

COMMENT 2: I still provide mobile visits but also wanted to have a brick n mortar space to fully live out the vision I have.   I think it‚Äôs important to really think out what you want to do with your business and if having a clinic space helps move you toward that goal.  For me I envisioned having a space that I could host workshops and education seminars to help the community and I wanted to be able to offer other services that can‚Äôt be provided in a mobile setting.

I also think it‚Äôs important not to rush into a space, make sure it‚Äôs the best fit for you before taking the leap.

post_text: I am in the process of buying a new vehicle and thinking about putting it under the business for ‚Äúbusiness use‚Äù. I asked about car insurance and they are wanting to put me on a commercial plan, which I am assuming will be more than personal use. Currently I just use my personal vehicle for my mobile business, I am a sole proprietor LLC. Does anyone have any advice on if I should just keep my vehicle separate from the business? I am in the growing phase and haven‚Äôt taken off financial yet. In other words I want the tax benefits but I also don‚Äôt wanna break the bank on insurance.

comments.text: When I consulted with a trusted insurance broker (close friend of mine‚Ä¶not scammy at all), she said if you plan to use your car to travel to and from your work, it‚Äôs strongly recommended to add non-hired auto to your malpractice bundle. If you get into an accident your personal auto insurance won‚Äôt cover damages. You can typically add non hired on to your business‚Äô personal, professional, cyber etc for a reasonable annual fee. I wound up not using it (I live in an urban area and mainly use public transportation) but remember it not being a significant amount.
My accountant told me to buy under personal, but could still write off as business. I would check your state laws and with your accountant.

full_thread_text:
POST: I am in the process of buying a new vehicle and thinking about putting it under the business for ‚Äúbusiness use‚Äù. I asked about car insurance and they are wanting to put me on a commercial plan, which I am assuming will be more than personal use. Currently I just use my personal vehicle for my mobile business, I am a sole proprietor LLC. Does anyone have any advice on if I should just keep my vehicle separate from the business? I am in the growing phase and haven‚Äôt taken off financial yet. In other words I want the tax benefits but I also don‚Äôt wanna break the bank on insurance.

COMMENT 1: When I consulted with a trusted insurance broker (close friend of mine‚Ä¶not scammy at all), she said if you plan to use your car to travel to and from your work, it‚Äôs strongly recommended to add non-hired auto to your malpractice bundle. If you get into an accident your personal auto insurance won‚Äôt cover damages. You can typically add non hired on to your business‚Äô personal, professional, cyber etc for a reasonable annual fee. I wound up not using it (I live in an urban area and mainly use public transportation) but remember it not being a significant amount.

COMMENT 2: My accountant told me to buy under personal, but could still write off as business. I would check your state laws and with your accountant.

post_text: For those doing home visits...do you use any spray or other preventative measures to decrease the risk of bringing home bed bugs or other things??

comments.text:
Look up home health bag technique on YouTube. It helps to prevent the spread of infestation and infection. 

I know my areas well and know when not to bring my bag in home and only bring in the bare essentials (based on area). If there is bed bugs you are required to follow contact precautions and wear the appropriate PPE. 

On your initial evaluation you need to assess the home for things like this. I suggest always carrying extra trash bags and clothing with you each day for your own safety. 

I‚Äôve been doing HH for several years now. Hope this helps.

If I wear shoe booties, bring my own seat, and only bring in necessary items, am I ok? I plan to throw away the booties after I'm done. Should I bring a change of shoes? Changing clothes seems tricky to manage while keeping things clean. If I only sit on my own seat, and wipe things down with disinfectant wipes before putting them in my car, am I good?

post_text: Has anyone had success getting referrals from social workers who work in rehabs? Thought this would be a great idea. I‚Äôve had good back and forth convos via e mail, met with some in person, brought pizza, but haven‚Äôt gotten much from them and it‚Äôs been 3 weeks. They make it seem like there‚Äôs such demand, but I‚Äôm sitting here like hello? Remmeber i said i can see your people ASAP?

comments.text: It might be that the medical reason and need for multiple disciplines that qualified them for inpatient rehab means needing a nurse and OT and/or SLP post discharge and HH can do all of that. People also like that HH is paid at 100% by Medicare and they might not have a supplement to cover the Med B 20% so patients ‚Äúpick‚Äù HH. I see that all the time in ALFs. The patient could easily be seen by Med B but HH is coming in instead.

Generally speaking most (not all) clients when they leave rehabs will qualify as homebound which under Medicare is paid 100% for a home health agency/ provider so most will go that route because there is no copay. Once they are no longer homebound they do not qualify for HH. Also transportation is NOT a qualifier under Medicare to make you homebound. You may have ‚Äúno way‚Äù to get transportation but are physically able to leave the home, Medicare will not pay for home health that way. So I would for sure try to contact home health companies for referrals after HH. some advantage plans are getting super stingey and despite being homebound and needing more therapy won‚Äôt authorize anymore. Our home health company opened a part B at home service line to account for these issues, you potentially could be the solution to a HH companies clients who are out of payment through HH

post_text: Hey y'all. I am exploring options to take my 100% mobile practice to partially at a physical location. Those who have done this- Did you change your price per session when you switched from mobile to physical location? Thanks!

comments.text: I don't think changing locations necessitates a change in cost. Your time is still your time.

When I went to brick and mortar from mobile, I was planning to differentiate my costs, but didn't end up doing much mobile since people just came to me now. It worked out üôÇ 

I do sometimes do in home/onsite/at hotel or temp residence for people that are coming through my city with performance groups/filming.  For that situation, if  i'm traveling outside of a 5 mile radius from my home or office, I add a $15 travel fee to my standard hourly. If they are staying near where I work or live, or filing at the studio 3 miles from my house, I don't charge that fee. 

So short answer, my treatment time fee is the same if they come to me or I go to them, but I do consider my time traveling to someone in my billing and will charge the travel fee as needed.  I'm completely cash based if that matter.

full_thread_text:

post_text:
Just wanted to share a little success. I started my mobile cash based practice as a side gig at the end of July. Still have a full time job in home health but squeeze in what I can, where I can, while keeping work life balance. In two months I‚Äôm now averaging around $800/week just on the side which is incredible. I was having trouble valuing myself in the beginning, but I had 3 new evaluations this week at $175 and have had really good positive feedback. Was told it was ‚Äúworth every penny‚Äù just this morning. 
So just go for it. Provide good service and produce some results and you will be successful. The most positive feedback I have received is the value in educating your clients on what is going on, and what the recovery process looks like so they understand what they are getting into. Good luck to you all!

post_text:
I have a patient with orders to start outpatient services S/P Reverse TSA. He is already seeing a nurse from Home Health for the same. Home Heath PT evaluated and DC‚Äôd after saying he needs Outpatient. Can I see him for O/P PT when he is already receiving services from Home Health?As per my understanding one can not seek outpatient services when receiving Home Health, due to billing concerns. Is that true or false as he is not receiving PT from Home Health? 

Please advise.

comments.text: Always ask about home health on your discovery call before setting up the appointments. Patients think since it‚Äôs different disciplines they don‚Äôt understand 2 different payment models can‚Äôt be covered simultaneously

Has to be an AGENCY discharge from home health to bill part B services, not just PT discharge. Home health part A services is paying the agency to provide all nursing and therapy needs. Whether or not they‚Äôre actually providing the therapy services or just nursing, a part B therapy claim will still get rejected - or paid now and you‚Äôll get a recoupment letter later.

full_thread_text:
POST: I have a patient with orders to start outpatient services S/P Reverse TSA. He is already seeing a nurse from Home Health for the same. Home Heath PT evaluated and DC‚Äôd after saying he needs Outpatient. Can I see him for O/P PT when he is already receiving services from Home Health?As per my understanding one can not seek outpatient services when receiving Home Health, due to billing concerns. Is that true or false as he is not receiving PT from Home Health? 

Please advise.

COMMENT 1: Always ask about home health on your discovery call before setting up the appointments. Patients think since it‚Äôs different disciplines they don‚Äôt understand 2 different payment models can‚Äôt be covered simultaneously

COMMENT 2: Has to be an AGENCY discharge from home health to bill part B services, not just PT discharge. Home health part A services is paying the agency to provide all nursing and therapy needs. Whether or not they‚Äôre actually providing the therapy services or just nursing, a part B therapy claim will still get rejected - or paid now and you‚Äôll get a recoupment letter later.

post_text: Hi.  What is the difference between Mobile PT and home health?

comments.text: A lot less documentation

Home Health is billed under Medicare part A, physicians have to sign orders and patients have to be home bound , usually only lasting a couple of weeks, falls under PDGM, must have qualifying verbage in clinical notes for medical necessity.  Mobile PT is OP PT in home, billed under Medicare PArt B, only needs a script, pt does not need to be home bound, treatments are closer to an hr and duration can be longer than HH.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hi.  What is the difference between Mobile PT and home health?

COMMENT 1: A lot less documentation

COMMENT 2: Home Health is billed under Medicare part A, physicians have to sign orders and patients have to be home bound , usually only lasting a couple of weeks, falls under PDGM, must have qualifying verbage in clinical notes for medical necessity.  Mobile PT is OP PT in home, billed under Medicare PArt B, only needs a script, pt does not need to be home bound, treatments are closer to an hr and duration can be longer than HH.

Okay, it's time to see my first patient.. 

Mobile PT's - what equipment do you use the most? Would love some links to your fav equipment (portable table, lotions, etc). After creating my LLC months ago, I am officially going to begin marketing this week! LET'S GO!!

comments.text:
*Portable massage table
*Foam balance pad
Foldable portable stool
Cleaning wipes
*Set of resistance loops
*Set of resistance tubes that latch onto handles or ankle loops
*Masking or painter's tape 
*BP cuff and pulse ox
*3-4 foot PVC pipe (or a broomstick)
Manual/IASTM tools of your choice
Masks (if you plan to mask)
Loved my latching clipboard when I had it, but making do without
*Reliable device to do notes on and take pictures/video (no cloud uploading, though)

On my wishlist right now are:
Car compatible charging port for my laptop (mine requires a üîå outlet)
Adjustable agility hurdles

Also, since you're probably about to spend a lot more time in the car (congrats on getting things rolling!), a good lunch box for cold car snacks and drinks. üôÉ

BP cuff, stethoscope & pulse ox, reflex hammer, goniometer, inclinometer, stop watch; cheap agility set with cones, ladder & hurdles, aerobic step, therabands (don‚Äôt leave them in sun/heat they melt), kinesiotape, foam roller, basic first aid kit. Adjustable crutches, collapsible straight cane. Painter‚Äôs tape to temporarily mark floor/walls. Travel massage table (too light = too narrow & flimsy), paper gowns (I put them on the table instead of a sheet). Pre-printed handouts with basic info re: managing acute conditions, favorite exercise routines. Good luck!!!

COMMENT 1: I‚Äôm in home health, even if we dc our patients I would not feel ok taking them on as part b or wellness because as a home care patient they still have the option to private pay if their insurance does not cover continued services. post_text: I started with a new cash based mobile PT client in a Skilled  Nursing Facility this week and had plans to work with this individual a few times per week. However, the daughter has now informed the facility doesn't allow outside services, but can pay their PTs if additional services are needed. Does anyone know the rules on this and does that sound right for the family to not have a choice on who they use for PT Services? Any help is appreciated.

comments.text: Eric Avery -- yes, that is true (this is the same situation before in the place where I was a DOR). And it's because of liability issues. Also, all SNF staff in the nursing home needs to comply with AHCA & other regulations (such as facilities preparing for annual surveys). SNFs, however, do allow outside services. Still, there has to be an agreement ‚Äúcompany to company‚Äù (for example of services like diagnostics) and the company has to show proof of malpractice insurance, etc., for the SNF administrator to sign the agreement. - for the situation you have.. the SNF has a rehab department, then the rehab staff in the SNF will provide the service.

post_text: I‚Äôd love to say I‚Äôm just nosy but I‚Äôm really just curious. What are your clinic‚Äôs (or clinics‚Äô) average units billed per session?? Mine from 2022 Mobile 3.44 brick and mortar 3.42

comments.text:
Right at 4 mobile. 3.9 I think. 

Some 5 unit visits (evals, longer tx times for higher level pts) get offset by 1-2 unit visits when tolerance is low, pt having an off day, etc when tx cut short.

I‚Äôm pretty consistently billing 4 units for standard treatment. I cant justify driving out to a clients home to do 3 units. I do 55/60 min treatments because i can only do time math by 5 mins LOL obviously it will vary. sometimes it‚Äôs 3 units, really really rarely is it 2 units and at that point I‚Äôm telling the pt to cancel if they can‚Äôt do a full session of therapy (24+ hour notice). I have some maintenance Geris but mostly younger athletic groups though.

Hi everyone! I'm not yet uncaged, but looking for someone who is. I work in hospital based OP, and have a patient who really requires more supervision and tx than we can offer right now at my clinic. In addition, the pt doesn't drive, and her niece has had to cancel a ton of appointments because she can't drive her here every week. She's been coming in for balance and we've mostly been working on strengthening, with a little vestibular training thrown in. Even with comprehensive note -taking she just doesn't remember cues by the time she gets home, and sometimes doesn't remember having talked about an exercise at all. BUT she's really pleasant, and hilarious. 

All that to be said, she'd benefit from in-home care, but can't get it through the hospital system because she's not home bound.

Anyone mobile in the Portland, OR area who takes Medicare? I'd love to be able to offer her a name or two to contact. Seems like she's also willing to consider self-pay, but she's paid into Medicare her whole life and should be able to use it.

Thank you!

post_text:
I‚Äôm seriously considering leaving the hospital setting and starting my own practice by myself. I‚Äôm hesitant to do it because of all the energy and time starting a new company takes with small kids at home. I feel I don‚Äôt have much more time or energy to give to something else but I want a change in schedule and more flexibility. I‚Äôm a person that needs to know numbers. How do I find out what the private practice- self employed (1 clinician) makes in a year and how many hours they work?  And have this related to my geographic location? I need a comparison locally. Also need to look at other benefits- what does insurance cost and where would you go through for medical benefits as I would loose good medica benefits, PTO, retirement matching, etc.
Thanks!

comments.text: I am currently starting my own mobile outpatient practice. Been working on it since about May of this year, and just launched my website last weekend looking to start taking patients in January. My kids are 3, 5, and 6. I did the uncaged boot camp classes in the evenings, and I took a course to become certified in my specialty by waking up at 5am to do the coursework while everyone else slept. I developed my own website in the evenings or on weekends until it was ready to launch, and now I don‚Äôt have to mess with it. My sister also started her own mobile outpatient practice with four kids at home. It‚Äôs definitely do-able, but you have to look at how you‚Äôre spending your time and give yourself grace to develop it slowly if it‚Äôs really what‚Äôs best for your family life. In the meantime, I still work full time in home health. If you went just PRN with a HH agency, you would probably have better pay and more flexibility. Good luck!

When my kids were little I really enjoyed working PRN,  because when I was working I could focus on work but when I came home I was present for them. 

Now that they are a bit older I recently started my own mobile PT practice. Not gonna lie, I feel like it was a lot of work to get everything in place. But I'm a bit OCD lol...This might just be me but when my kids were little I would not have wanted that responsibility. The other thing is I don't need the benefits as my husband's are good.

Pay in my area...outpt PRN 40ish per hour, Home Health PRN 55-60 per visit plus wear and tear on your car. A lot more paperwork especially if you have to do start of cares, I find they are not worth it being PRN.

If you can find somewhere that does mobile outpatient PT in the home much easier on paperwork. 55 a visit in my area. The best way to do this is to sign on with a few companies and keep your area very  very small. Drive time is everything. 

For reference with Medicare and the supplement I get about 105 a visit, with my mobile PT practice and I am doing my own billing and pay for my own equipment car,  gas, all that. But look at the pay difference...I feel like it's worth doing it on my own. 105 vs 55...no brainer.
Another good option if you're not ready to take the leap is look into Luna in my area they pay about 70 a visit mobile outpatient PT in the home. I know people give them a lot of shade but I love working for them too. I'm an independent contractor with them so they help fill in my schedule a bit. Plus guaranteed pay on the spot
Super easy paperwork and you can just focus on treating.

Please feel free to reach out to me if you have more questions

post_text: This question is for a family member of mine. She is receiving PT through a mobile Medicare B provider. Family wants to have a nurse from local hospital home care agency come in to do an assessment. Her memory is not good amd she does not live alone but other person does not really want to be a care giver. They are hoping they could get a home health aide in as well as an OT. For some ADL/ cognitive work. I was told after speaking to the home care agency she can‚Äôt have the PT in while she is receiving services for Medicare part A. As Medicare will only cover one or the other. She is home bound as can‚Äôt drive. The part B provider thinks this only applies to days he would be in apartment. So on days he‚Äôs not in Medicare part A providers can come in amd bill. Does anyone know rules on this. Is it one vs the other or can it be mixed. She likes the PT already coming into home amd has been getting it for a few months from them. This is mainly about getting a home health aide to be covered for a period of time by Medicare and that has to go through a certified agency.

comments.text: She can not have Med Part B PT and Med Part A PT at the same time.  Meaning, only 1 plan of care can be carried out at once.  She will have to choose either staying with the Part B OR switching to home health to use Part A.

Once admitted to home health, the med B PT is giving visits for free until discharged completely from home health agency. Home health service has a certification period usually lasting 60 days but can be shorter or longer depending on patient needs. Med A pays for the period, not per visit.

post_text:
Is there anyone in this group that maintains a mobile private practice as well as teaches part time?Ôøº

I‚Äôm convinced that if I maintain working in the clinical sense, I want to try and get my own business going with some contract home health/outpatient coverage as needed while it builds up.

I have been entertaining the move to teaching for a bit but logistically couldn‚Äôt consider it as we don‚Äôt want to leave the area where we live. The nearest physical therapy program is about 1.5 hours away. ÔøºWith the development of hybrid programs, it‚Äôs becoming a possibility to teach and not have to move.ÔøºÔøº

I know a lot of faculty at PT programs treat on the side. Most of these are in clinic or outpatient rehab department settings. I‚Äôm trying to see if it‚Äôs feasible to do the same thing with my own mobile practice.Ôøº

comments.text: You can also check out PTA programs or even college courses like anatomy. I am a site supervisor for one university and hoping to get involved as a lab instructor at another school. But I'm not a full time PT rn. I can definitely see it working out and I think it would be a really unique experience for students to see you doing mobile outpatient

I do! My semester starts next week and I‚Äôm already anticipating lots of chaos! I teach a lecture and lab, so it‚Äôs 9 hours per week of standing in front of a class with 4 different presentations for 12 weeks. My mobile practice was muuuch smaller last time I was lead teacher (I assisted lab this spring and that was manageable as I didn‚Äôt have much out of class responsibilities). I‚Äôm at the PT program 2 days/week and squeezing my caseload into the other three days. Weekends and late nights are I guess when I‚Äôll do notes and update course content/grade (after my own kids have worn me out). Sorry, I realize this might scare you! I really love teaching and love seeing the students turn into professionals!! Feel free to PM me if you have other questions.

full_thread_text:
POST: Is there anyone in this group that maintains a mobile private practice as well as teaches part time?Ôøº

I‚Äôm convinced that if I maintain working in the clinical sense, I want to try and get my own business going with some contract home health/outpatient coverage as needed while it builds up.

I have been entertaining the move to teaching for a bit but logistically couldn‚Äôt consider it as we don‚Äôt want to leave the area where we live. The nearest physical therapy program is about 1.5 hours away. ÔøºWith the development of hybrid programs, it‚Äôs becoming a possibility to teach and not have to move.ÔøºÔøº

I know a lot of faculty at PT programs treat on the side. Most of these are in clinic or outpatient rehab department settings. I‚Äôm trying to see if it‚Äôs feasible to do the same thing with my own mobile practice.Ôøº

COMMENT 1: You can also check out PTA programs or even college courses like anatomy. I am a site supervisor for one university and hoping to get involved as a lab instructor at another school. But I'm not a full time PT rn. I can definitely see it working out and I think it would be a really unique experience for students to see you doing mobile outpatient

My mobile practice was muuuch smaller last time I was lead teacher (I assisted lab this spring and that was manageable as I didn‚Äôt have much out of class responsibilities). I‚Äôm at the PT program 2 days/week and squeezing my caseload into the other three days. Weekends and late nights are I guess when I‚Äôll do notes and update course content/grade (after my own kids have worn me out). Sorry, I realize this might scare you! I really love teaching and love seeing the students turn into professionals!! Feel free to PM me if you have other questions.
